There was tons of guacamole and cheese in the burrito too. We were very happy that they weren't stingy with the ingredients or meat in the burrito either. They also give you chips to eat and there's a fresh salsa bar as well. Overall this was a great little place to eat, even though it's inside the corner of a grocery market. We would definitely go back and enjoy eating here in the future.
author: Chris T.

description:
This place is great.  I am the product of three generation of Swedish Mexican pig farmers. Therefore, I am uniquely qualified to know that the carnitas here are succulent and ripe with flavor. 

This place offers a burrito in the TL superior to Cancun (on Market), superior to all the Castilitos, and easily on par with the savory All-Star tamales at the farmers market.

This place is ridiculously clean for a taqueria. Especially a place in the TL. Cancun is a great burrito, but I always feel like I'm going to find some dirt in my burrito (much less get accosted inside the place). Clean cooking area and clean seating area - solid. 

Awesome selection of 6 salsas.

If you order a "salad" at a TAQUERIA you deserve ZERO stars.
author: Sven S.

description:
My fish taco order took WAY too long (about five other people's orders were processed in the meantime) and when I finally did get it, it was soggy, bland and littered with absurd amounts of cilantro.

I was not a fan - tossed the remaining two thirds into the rubbish bin and mentally psyched myself up for the daunting walk back to the hotel.
author: Kat F.

description:
The portions are good, the food is tasty. While waiting for your food, you can peruse one of the best stocked convenience stores in the neighborhood. There are cheaper taquerias in the 'Loin, but this is probably my favorite. 

Now if only they had half orders for nachos.
author: Matt W.

description: Great food! The flautas are fabulous and it's a large portion!
author: Emma S.

description: If you are too hungover or too hungry to get all the way to the mission for a bomb authentic burrito this is the place to go. Everything on the menu is amazing (real talk). The burritos are huge, the chicken is amazing, the salsa bar is diverse. No complaints, so glad I found you El Tesoro! Its a hidden gem within a grocery store, which also means you know its fresh.
author: Donna H.

description:
I finally tried El Tesoro on my way home from work a few weeks ago and was very happy with my burrito.  Well-prepared burrito with the right proportion of good ingredients.  Chips were decent (and they don't charge extra) and the place is pretty big, so plenty of seating.

They didn't have bottles of Tapatio sitting out, I had to ask for it but they have it behind the counter.  They're open pretty late too, which is nice.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Joseph N.

description: I won't recomment anybody to try It. First, It is not a restaurent . It is a supermaket. The food is not very tasty.The restaurent is in a wacky neighborhood.holy moly!!
author: Jerome B.

description: Tacos were awesome. Not tiny not dry... We stayed right across street from here. Wish I would've know about this place earlier in vacation.
author: Tony M.

description:
I consistently hit this place up for a burrito.

Carnitas could be more crispy. Sometimes the burritos are huge and sometimes not so much. Sometimes the tortillas are deliciously fried to a golden hue, sometimes equally yummy charred and smoky, sometimes neither. Not a huge fan of the pico de gallo here but their orange habanero sauce is bomb.
author: Anthony B.

description:
After looking this restaurant up and seeing all the great reviews I decided to try it.  I am visiting San Francisco and was craving some Mexican food.  Most of the other restaurants were closed because I was looking for a late night snack at 11PM.  

The first thing I discovered, it is located inside a grocery store called MID CITY.  This makes it very convenient but hard to find if you don't know what you are looking for.  The service was great, although they don't really understand English.  They understood enough to give me my order exactly how I wanted it.

The food was spectacular, and for a very inexpensive price.  The servings are huge.  So don't over order, or you will have plenty of left over's.  As for the location itself, it's a hole in a wall.  I didn't go there for the decor or ambience.  I went there for the great and affordable food.  They had great service and were very fast.  I would definitely go back.
author: Stephan T.

description: This place is amazing and I don't get hyperbolic often. I ate here for the first time about a week ago and, I kid you not, I have eaten here every day since. It really feels like what a taqueria should. It is a little weird that it is house in a convenience store, but don't let that detract from the fantastic. The food is great. I can say with out hesitation that this is literally my favorite place to get a burrito. Even the complimentary salsa is exquisite. Stop reading this and just go give it a try already!
author: Stephen C.

description: Great burritos and tacos, among other things. The prices are definitely reasonable and they have a great selection of Mexican beer, most being only $2. Good people watching as well. And yes, this little place is inside a market, no biggie. Oh and there is a daily Happy Hour from 3-5 or so, with deals on drinks as well as food.
author: Bass T.

description: Burritos are so delish ! Will definitely recommend this taqueria! Awesome people!
author: Beth G.

description:
My favorite Taqueria in the whole bay area; and it's inside a liquor store.  How much better can it get?

The prices some of the more reasonable around and the portions are some of the most generous.   They have a large selection of items other than your standard burrito (tostadas, roast chicken, tortas, flautas-- you get the picture).

The free chips are homemade, thin and delicious...

Today I tried the breakfast burrito (+steak) and it was awesome.  It was essentially just a regular burrito with an extra kick of protein from the egg.  I also highly recommend trying the bbq chicken or bbq pork (pastor).

They have a tendency to go a little overboard with the rice here, so I'd recommend asking for "less rice".  There's also a good collection of salsas and jalapenos available if you need a little more spice.
author: Rocco B.

description:
Came here with Annie and Shawn yesterday mid afternoon, Annie spotted this place and thought that we should check it out and so we did.
This place is a Mexican place to eat at a  grocery store. 
The service was good, the place looked very clean and the food was really
good. I will be back.
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
New outpost of the smaller original a scant three blocks away.

Fifteen seats along several tables and a counter span the western 1/3 of a cheerful high-ceilinged mini-supermarket.  Over a generous heaping plate of cheesy tex-mex fresh-grilled meat with the usual salad, guacamole, rice, beans, five kinds of salsa, limes there was a constant drone of small children singing mexi-rap on the radio, families with kids running around, cashiers yelling across the room at stock boys.  

Burritos go $5.45 for standard to $9.50 for the steak and prawn.  A few extras beyond basic taqueria -- four kinds of soup, breakfast, eleven meats from chicken up through lengua and cabeza but nothing scarier than that. Vegetarian option is grilled red and green peppers fried on a grill dripping with beef fat.  Homemade chips were fresh and good.

Some great extra features -- a strong wifi signal from elsewhere, big storefront windows on the sunny site of the street, an ATM, adequate heat.  Best for last: you can buy extra food and alcohol in the grocery to eat at your table!
author: Gil S.

description:
So far I have not had a bad experience here.
I've had the burrito (SO BIG!! I ate half one day and the other half the next. very filling) with chicken. I've had the tostada and the tamale plate. The have delish black beans and their tamales are pretty good (and spicey). 

I'm a big fan of their rice too- the peas and carrots are never extemely soggy ( I'm not a big fan of mushy veggies in my rice, thanks). One of my favorite taquerias in the area. And I think on average I get a huge meal for under $8. Can't beat that.

Oh, and even though I'm from South America all I can manage to say is "hello" in spanish. They always speak to me in spanish and I have to make a sad face and say "no habla espanol" :( They're always extremely nice so whoever says there is bad service here is most likely a prick who gave them attitude to begin with ;)
author: Amanda S.

description:
The food is pretty good, but it is insanely expensive... 3 dollars for a little taco is rediculous. Burritos are the industry standard 7 bucks or so but damn 3 tacos usually costs like 6 bucks not 10.

But all of that could be forgiven if it wasnt for one thing.... The employees there do not consider the fact that many Californians understand spanish. When your sitting there listening to them make fun of you and the other white customers in spanish its hard to want to go back.
author: Val M.

description: Ordered the Chile-Verde Super Burrito and man it was YUMMO!! I will be returning back.
author: Vincent D.

description: Man, I wanted to like this place since both of their TL locations are so close but the food's just gross. I got fries and they tasted really rancid - like they were made with super old oil. Then I tried their nachos and it was 98% soggy toppings and three corn chips. Obviously I'm exaggerating but not by much.
author: Catherine C.

description: This was it.  This (I thought just by virtue of the preparation), was the SD style burrito I've been looking for.  Perfect (and i mean PERFECT) tortilla.  Really good meat.  Really good pico de gallo.  Ideal proportions.  Then, my corazon was broken: really mediocre guac.  This was the SD style burrito beauty queen that got beat up when the ugly SF style burrito heard she was in town. No you dit-ent SD style burrito at El Tesoro, no you dit-ent...but you were damned close.
author: Paul M.

description: Good neighborhood taqueria with friendly service. Burritos never disappoint and they have a good salsa selection. Not quite the mission though!
author: Avinash S.

description: Love this place. Authentic taqueria. It's in the corner of a market. The prices are low for the size of the portions. The food is really good. Carnitas are excellent as are the chicharrones when they have them. Great salsa bar too.
author: Anthony B.

description: El Tesoro is kind of like my designated late night burrito destination when I am starving. They whip up a very tasty burrito. I have had the super burrito with pollo en salsa and al pastor. Eating one of these burritos isn't a life changing moment by any stretch of the imagination, but I think it's worth a try. On some nights it's brilliant and on others not so much; that's part of why I am giving it only 3 stars.
author: Eric M.

description: woo hoo! best mexican i've had in the tl! i recommend the carne asada chimichanga.
author: Nigel B.

description:
A really, really good super burrito. The tortilla is tasty and chewy, a perfect blend - not thick and leathery like some taquerias (Pancho's), nor thin and prone to rupture as at others (La Canasta). And it's griddled just right, browned even -- delish!

So lessee. I happen to have an El Tesoro super burrito right here. The pollo asado is fine, though my preference would be to blacken it up like Gordo's does. There are peas and carrots in these babies -- a thoughtful little enhancement.
 
I just picked up the second half and gooey cheese dripped out. That's a burrito, mmm-mmmm good.

And get this - they have a HAPPY HOUR for burritos! Between 3 and 5 p.m. a regular is $4 and a super is $5. Compare that to $8.60 or so with tax for a super at the overpriced El Patron a block to the west. And they have a steamer so once the burrito is in foil, they zap it so it's piping hot. You don't see that at a lot of taquerias, and it should warm the cockles of any burrito-lover's heart.

More -- there's a nice, clean salsa bar with a variety of selections. Two are green and they're legitimately spicy, and this from a guy who puts Dave's Insanity Sauce on his Cheerios. There's a pleasant seating area from which one may watch the entertaining drama that is the Tenderloin through an open-air window. Upbeat Mexican music plays in the background.

Another poster panned the place after ordering a green salad and French fries. Um, it's a freaking taqueria. Get a freaking burrito!
author: Fred S.

description: Great food at great prices. Carnitas, shrimps are really yummy. Not a fan of their tortillas, chips or fries though.
author: Erik C.

description: This place was alright. Having recently moved into the area I've kinda been feeling the restaurants around here out and I doubt that I'll be a regular at this one. I bit into a chunk of bone in my burrito which kinda sucks. They're a little pricier than the other taqueria down the block and not as good in my opinion. The one good thing that this place does have is a salsa bar with like 6 different salsas, all really good. Sometimes I feel like going into Chunky's for food then just coming here to get some salsa. Don't think they'd appreciate that though.
author: Tommy P.

description: Ok, I swear this place was better but yesterday my burrito was the PITS. Cold and undercooked (umm I don't eat meat, but gimme a break...my veggies were raw and my rice cold). Plus where are the beans?? I barely saw any wrapped in my tortilla! I have issues with the rice as well. First off, why is it orange? Secondly, I don't want peas in my burrito. And I love peas, but that's just weird to me. Eating peas with avocado just doesn't seem right. Maybe it was an off day???
author: Brittany L.

description: Best spot in the TL for a burrito. I mean its still not as great as some of the Mission taquerias, but hey its open late, reasonably priced and everything I have had has been pretty good.
author: Vilen G.

description: Saw a review of this place on a burrito blog and since it's so close to where I live, I figured I'd give it a shot. i was not disappointed. Though maybe not as crazy good as some spots in the mission, the chicken burrito I got was made quickly, with the ingredients incorporated well, and quite flavorful. I didn't feel that it was too greasy or wet from salsa, beans, etc. The meat was tasty, tender and didn't have grissle. It was exactly what I was craving and it was exactly what I got.
author: Barbara J.

description: Tasty Mexican meals whipped up quickly. Friendly service and grocery store attached. Great Mexican food for the neighborhood (because selection is limited!)  but the (un)cleanliness might be a bit too much for some.
author: Anne A.

description: bonus for open late for a street taco without having to go to the mission.  only got a single taco (al pastor) and they forget the additives.  average flavor.
author: Rob C.

description: eh skip this taqueria. cold burrito after a 20 minute wait. no thanks
author: Jaide F.

description: They didn't mind when my roommate and I came in and had a food fight at their salsa bar.
author: Randall T. Bogus, I.

description: Okay, I love El Tesoro...but whoever catagorized it as Tex-Mex has never been to Texas. It is stricktly California taqeria food. Its good, better than most...but NOT tex-mex.
author: Susan L.

description: These people are on drugs. They look at you like they're sorry they have to give you this crap. then they give it to you and ask for money. We ordered a green salad and some French fries hoping that this could be a simple enough task for an orangutan to do blindfolded. No such luck. The salad was old and withered hidden under some cO2 sprayed tomatoes. The fries were limper than bob dole. I get a queasy nausea whenever I walk by. Utterly Offended.
author: N O.

description: wonder g.. who da f@!$ orders a salad and fries at this place!!! funny!!
author: giovanni o.
